title: New method of making lab-grown meat spins gelatin fibers like cotton candy for realistic texture
text:
A new method of conjuring lab-grown meat may forever change the way you look at cotton candy.

Researchers from Harvard say they can now spin gelatin fibers using a device inspired by a cotton candy machine.

The result, which are published in Nature, is a lab-grown meat closer in texture to the protein carnivores know and love, they say.

Much like its cotton candy-creating kin, the machine spins at high speeds - 30,000 rotations per minute - to create a type of gelatin scaffold on which animal cells can grow.

Gelatin fibers create by researchers can be seen above and act as a frame for animal cells to grow and replicate into meat

The gelatin is woven at 30,000 RPM and helps to give the meat its texture and also tenderness

According to them, the product, which was tested against household meats like bacon, beef tenderloin, and rabbit, using a more closely resembles the tightly packed muscle tissue and subsequent texture found in naturally created meat.

The gelatin, which is created from breaking down pig collagen, not only helps to create the framework for the meat, but also helps to make it desirably tender.

Researchers say the gelatin fibers are also long and malleable much like the skeletal muscle fibers that fuse into the muscle and produce chicken and cow tissue as we know it.

'You don't want the cells to be like bricks in a brick building,' Kit Parker, the Tarr Family Professor of Bioengineering and Applied Physics at SEAS and senior author of the study told Wired.

'You want them to be nice and long, like that pulled pork. So having these long fibers, the cells attach to the fibers and they form protein junctions, and then they grow along the length of the fiber.'

While the method had brought researchers closer to creating a lab-grown meat that convincingly parrots its organic counterpart, there are still many hurdles before it ends up on consumers' dinner plates.

Researchers hope to use the technique to replicate different meat like prosciutto (pictured above) and have reported success in testing the lab-grown tissue against the real thing

Among them, are the cost of producing the meat which relies on animal serums that promote cell growth which are difficult to manufacture.

Additionally, researchers have not been able to actually consume the meat that they grow in the lab due to safety concerns.

Regardless of the obvious hurdles between researchers and mass production of lab-grown meat using the method, they say incremental progress like there's could help ultimately ween reliance on animal farming and reduce humans' environmental footprint.

'Moving forward, the goals are nutritional content, taste, texture, and affordable pricing. The long-range goal is reducing the environmental footprint of food,' said Parker.
